DRC is redistributing its COVAX allocated doses as they are set to expire on 24 June 2021. It will recover those doses from COVAX at a later stage and hence has been classified as a 'loan'. The redistribution is also taking place through COVAX. In total 1.3m doses will be redistributed.

India has already sent 0.15m of the total promised doses. Reports do not mention donation or purchase but is most likely a donation

2 shipments of 0.1m each. The vaccine shipment is part of India's neighbourhood first foreign policy as 'under grant assistance', and delivered on 20 jan. The govt hopes to ship about 1m doses to Bhutan. This shipment is among the first in the line of countries set to receive vaccine doses from India and also the first in South Asia. This also puts India ahead of China which had also committed to supplying vaccine in the South Asian region. Pakistan is reportedly left out of this vaccine assistance.
HT reported 0.15m doses, but official govt sources report 0.1m, which is used here.

The vaccine shipment is part of India's neighbourhood first foreign policy as 'under grant assistance', and expected to be delivered on 21 jan. This also puts India ahead of China which had also committed to supplying vaccine in the South Asian region. Pakistan is reportedly left out of this vaccine assistance.

According to UN Peacekeeping, currently, a total of 94,484 personnel are serving in 12 peacekeeping operations across the world led by the Department of Peace Operations. The donation will allow vaccinations for all the personnel.

Thought to be in response to Czech Republic's promise to open a diplomatic office in Jerusalem. Plans for donation appear to be suspended after Israel came under criticism for sharing doses abroad before vaccinating Palestinians.

Thought to be in response to Guatemala moving its embassy to Jerusalem. Vaccines have arried in Guatemala, but plans for donation to other countries appear to be temporarily suspended after Israel was criticized for sending vaccines abroad before vaccinating Palestinians.

Thought to be in response to Honduras pledging to move its embassy to Jerusalem. Vaccines have been received, but plans for donations to other countries appear to be suspended after Israel was criticized for sending vaccines abroad before sharing with Palestinians.
It has been reported that Israel agreed to purchase an undisclosed number of Gamaleya vaccines in exchange for a prisoner swap in February 2021.

According to the Washington Post, the Palestinian health minister said on 20 Feb that Israel had agreed to providing 0.1m doses for Palestinian workers who regularly cross into Israel to work. Israel has yet to publicly confirm that arrangement. A different Reuters article reported that Israel had confirmed it will allocate 0.13m doses. This is in addition to the 5,000 doses to Palestinians for front-line medical workers. There are an estimated 5m Palestinians living in the Gaza Strip and the West Bank.

Israel and Palestine entered an agreement where Israel would send doses in exchange for "receiving a reciprocal number of doses" from Palestine later this year. However, this was cancelled as Palestine reportedly received doses that were set to expire soon
Unclear which vaccine(s) will be donated or whether the vaccines will be donated to COVAX or through bilateral donations

Reports suggest Norway has donated nearly 700,000 doses as of March 2021 and plans to donate up to roughly 2m doses. These doses are the shares that Norway had reserved via COVAX, but it has chosen not to receive them and to have them sent to other countries instead. Given how allocations with COVAX work, it is not clear which vaccines will be donated, but so far it has been AstraZeneca.

South Africa sold its AZ doses to other AU states after a small trial found that the vaccine was not effective against the local variant. Unclear if vaccinations will be approved by the Palestinian President Mahmoud Abbas, as the donation has been secured by his political rival Mohammad Dahlan. Also unclear if Israel would allow transfer of doses from Gaza to West Bank.

The UK announced at the G7 summit in June 2021 that it will donate at least 100m of its surplus doses, and atleast 5m of these will be donated in coming weeks. Of the 100m, 80m will be donated to COVAX, the rest will be donated bilaterally

The UK announced at the G7 summit in June 2021 that it will donate at least 100m of its surplus doses, and atleast 5m of these will be donated in coming weeks. Of the 100m, 80m will be donated to COVAX, the rest will be donated bilaterally
The White House has stated that the vaccines would be a loan - vaccines would be shipped now in exchange for doses sent back to the US at a later date.

The White House has stated that the vaccines would be a loan - vaccines would be shipped now in exchange for doses sent back to the US at a later date. The donation/loan appears to be linked to ongoing negotiations over the flow of migrants at the US-Mexico border.

Initial reports suggested 0.013m doses of J&J will be supplied to the South Korean military by the US. The final agreement reached between the two governments did not mention which vaccine will be provided but said 0.55m doses will be provided. But 1m doses of J&J were finally sent to South Korea.

The US announced that of its donation of 80m doses, 75% (or 60m) will go through COVAX, while the rest will be donated bilaterally. On 3 June, it announced a distribution plan for the donation of 25m, followed by another announcement oon 22 June for the remaining 55m doses. Of the COVAX donations, individual countries earmarked to recieve donations have been announced but the amounts are unkwown. The individual donations and allocations will be decided by the US. Brazil, Guatemala, Honduras and Taiwan are among these recipients whose allocations are known (hence reduced total doses). Of the 19m doses, about 6m are for South and Central America, about 7m are for South and Southeast Asia, and about 5m are for Afria (to be decied with the African Union). Of the 41m doses (part of 2nd distribution plan), 14m are for Latin America and the Caribbean, 16m are for Asia, and 10m for Africa. The vaccines donated will be Pfizer, Moderna and J&J (Astrazeneca donation depends on FDA approval). The US had earlier stated that it will donate up to 60m doses of AstraZeneca vaccines and 20m doses of other vaccines. AZE will be donated pending safety clearance by the FDA in the coming weeks. Fill list of countries can be found in the links.

The US announced that of its donation of 80m doses, 75% (or 60m) will go through COVAX, while the rest 20m will be donated bilaterally. It also announced a distribution plan for the donation of 25m of the total 80m doses, which includes 6m doses that will be donated to specific countries. The distribution plan for the rest 14m doses is yet to be announced and hence recipient is marked 'Unclear'. The vaccine to be donated is unknown. Earlier, The US announced that it will send 20m doses of Pfizer, Moderna or J&J abroad, including those meant for domestic use as supply is exceeding demand. It had also stated that it will donate up to 60m doses of AstraZeneca vaccines, pending safety clearance by the FDA in the coming weeks.The donations are expected to begin in June.

US plans to donate 200m doses in 2021 and 300m in 2022 to 92 lower middle income countries and the African Union. Donation plan announced around the G7 summit and is part of the total 1b doses pledged. Doses will be purchased at not-for-profit rates from Pfizer and has an option to buy more doses. All donations are expected to be completed by June 2022.

The US is donating these doses to Taiwan through COVAX, and is part of the 19m plan for COVAX distribution. Doses announced after the 25m donation plan made public on June 3. Donation increased to 2.5m from the initial 0.75m
